image.altText: Four people stand on top of a truck, waving Egyptian flags at the Rafah border crossing.

items.synopsis: The Rafah border crossing between Egypt and Gaza will be reopened to allow foreign nationals out of the embattled Palestinian city, according to the US Secretary of State, although the exact timeline is not yet confirmed.Â Follow live.

title.children: Border crossing between Egypt and Palestinian territory set to reopen, allowing evacuations and aid

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There are plans to open the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt to allow aid into the region. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has said "Rafah will be reopened" to allow foreign nationals out, but we don't know the exact timeline yet. A spokesperson for the Israel Defense Forces says Hamas stopped the border from opening. "I know there have been discussions [about opening Rafah, but] I cannot yet confirm they have been fruitful," Jonathan Conricus said in a Twitter Q & A. "The day before yesterday we tried to get foreign nationals out of Gaza. That failed because Hamas refused to open the gate. Hamas don't want people to evacuate from northern Gaza to the south. They are not allowing the opening of the gates from Rafah to Egypt."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: IDF accuses Hamas of refusing to allow Rafah border crossing to open

children.content: There are plans to open the Rafah border crossing between Gaza and Egypt to allow aid into the region.
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has said "Rafah will be reopened" to allow foreign nationals out, but we don't know the exact timeline yet.
A spokesperson for the Israel Defense Forces says Hamas stopped the border from opening.
"I know there have been discussions [about opening Rafah, but] I cannot yet confirm they have been fruitful," Jonathan Conricus said in a Twitter Q
A.

"The day before yesterday we tried to get foreign nationals out of Gaza. That failed because Hamas refused to open the gate. Hamas don't want people to evacuate from northern Gaza to the south. They are not allowing the opening of the gates from Rafah to Egypt."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hundreds of metric tonnes of aid from several countries have been held up in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula for days pending a deal for its safe delivery to Gaza and the evacuation of some foreign passport holders through the Rafah crossing. "Rafah will be reopened. Weâre putting in place with the United Nations, with Egypt, with Israel, with others, a mechanism by which to get the assistance in and to get it to people who need it," US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said after a meeting with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi on Sunday. Blinken did not give a specific time for the crossing to reopen. Veteran US diplomat David Satterfield, appointed on Sunday as a special envoy for Middle East humanitarian issues, will arrive in Egypt on Monday to work out the details, Blinken said. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rafah border crossing in Egypt will be reopened, says US Secretary of State Antony Blinken

children.content: Hundreds of metric tonnes of aid from several countries have been held up in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula for days pending a deal for its safe delivery to Gaza and the evacuation of some foreign passport holders through the Rafah crossing.

"Rafah will be reopened. Weâre putting in place with the United Nations, with Egypt, with Israel, with others, a mechanism by which to get the assistance in and to get it to people who need it," US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said after a meeting with Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi on Sunday.

Blinken did not give a specific time for the crossing to reopen. Veteran US diplomat David Satterfield, appointed on Sunday as a special envoy for Middle East humanitarian issues, will arrive in Egypt on Monday to work out the details, Blinken said.

props.alt: An image of trucks lined up outside the Rafah crossing

children.content: Trucks carrying humanitarianÂ aidÂ to Palestinians wait for the Rafah border crossing to open
(Reuters: Stringer)
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As we anticipate Israel sending troops into Gaza, the president of the Middle East Institute in Washington DC says that would almost certainly bring Iran and Hezbollah into the war. Paul Salem tells ABC News "the risk is very high". "Hezbollah, which is very close to Iran, is already exchanging attacks with Israel on the Lebanon-Israel border â the highest escalation since 2006," he says. He says Hamas, as well as Iran and Hezbollah in Lebanon, would have known the attack would elicit a response from Israel. "You have to figure Hamas is prepared for elements of this invasion. They can hide and escape bombings easier than civilians can," Salem says. "If [Iran] find that Hamas is losing the battle, they might open a second front, which would put Israel and US in a difficult situation." US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and China are urging Iran and Hezbollah not to get involved. Blinken is meeting with Egypt to organise a corridor for American-Palestinians to get out. There are also discussions about trying to get aid to Gaza from Egypt, where president Abdel Fattah El-Sisi has said Israel's response went beyond the right to self defence.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Very high risk' Iran and Hezbollah get involved if Israel launches ground assault

children.content: As we anticipate Israel sending troops into Gaza, the president of the Middle East Institute in Washington DC says that would almost certainly bring Iran and Hezbollah into the war.
Paul Salem tells ABC News "the risk is very high".
"Hezbollah, which is very close to Iran, is already exchanging attacks with Israel on the Lebanon-Israel border â the highest escalation since 2006," he says.
He says Hamas, as well as Iran and Hezbollah in Lebanon, would have known the attack would elicit a response from Israel.
"You have to figure Hamas is prepared for elements of this invasion. They can hide and escape bombings easier than civilians can," Salem says.
"If [Iran] find that Hamas is losing the battle, they might open a second front, which would put Israel and US in a difficult situation."
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and China are urging Iran and Hezbollah not to get involved.
Blinken is meeting with Egypt to organise a corridor for American-Palestinians to get out.
There are also discussions about trying to get aid to Gaza from Egypt, where president Abdel Fattah El-Sisi has said Israel's response went beyond the right to self defence.

image.altText: Peter Dutton in the House of Representatives.

items.synopsis: Follow our live updates on the fallout from the Voice to Parliament referendum's defeat on Monday, October 16, 2023.

title.children: Coalition to review promise for constitutional recognition vote, Dutton says Australians 'probably over' referendum process

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In the fallout of the referendum's defeat, chief executive officer at Secretariat of National Aboriginal and Islander Child Care (SNAICC) Catherine Liddle said the practical way forward for Indigenous people, and the country, was to start by naming the truth telling process. "We really need to be honest about where we've come from, where we are right now, and what the steps we need [to take are] in order to reconcile those two things and step out the pathway," she said. "Now, we've been calling for truth telling for a very long time, and truth telling speaks to that. I'd really like to see the prime minister lean in on that." The Arrernte/Luritja woman from Central Australia, told ABC News that the next steps forward need to ensure Aboriginal people have agency in conversations and solutions made about them in an attempt to close the gap. "The path we went down ahead of referendum clearly isn't going to be the one we walk together but we do need to sort this out, we do need to keep moving because the issues that brought us to the referendum exist with us today, those stats relating to closing the gap still exist and they need a different solution and [that needs] to be a solution that's defined by Aboriginal people who know what is happening with the underlying drivers who know how to solve that," she said. She said it was important these "challenging" conversations were had in a way that do not damage vulnerable children. "I think that's about having kind conversations, that's about looking for hope, that's about looking for what comes next and charting that pathway," she said about protecting children post-referendum. "Being honest and being really aware what you say in public and how you say it is heard by our children. "And even when you look back at election night, children were watching, children were watching that result and they were watching how people responded."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Truth telling identified as a way forward post-referendum

props.alt: Catherine Iddle outside a building in a blue dress

children.content: Catherine Liddle.
(ABC News: Ian Redfearn)
In the fallout of the referendum's defeat, chief executive officer at Secretariat of National Aboriginal and Islander Child Care (SNAICC)
Catherine Liddle
said the practical way forward for Indigenous people, and the country, was to start by naming the truth telling process.
"We really need to be honest about where we've come from, where we are right now, and what the steps we need [to take are] in order to reconcile those two things and step out the pathway," she said.
Â
"Now, we've been calling for truth telling for a very long time, and truth telling speaks to that. I'd really like to see the prime minister lean in on that."
The Arrernte/Luritja woman from Central Australia, told
ABC News
that the next steps forward need to ensure Aboriginal people have agency in conversations and solutions made about them in an attempt to close the gap.

"The path we went down ahead of referendum clearly isn't going to be the one we walk together but we do need to sort this out, we do need to keep moving because the issues that brought us to the referendum exist with us today, those stats relating to closing the gap still exist and they need a different solution and [that needs] to be a solution that's defined by Aboriginal people who know what is happening with the underlying drivers who know how to solve that," she said.
Â
She said it was important these "challenging" conversations were had in a way that do not damage vulnerable children.

"I think that's about having kind conversations, that's about looking for hope, that's about looking for what comes next and charting that pathway," she said about protecting children post-referendum. "Being honest and being really aware what you say in public and how you say it is heard by our children.
"And even when you look back at election night, children were watching, children were watching that result and they were watching how people responded."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By Lauren Roberts The NT's chief minister said she was "disappointed" by the referendum results on Saturday night and now was the time to "reflect" on how to support the community moving forward. Chief Minister Natasha Fyles said numbers from remote polling stations in the Northern Territory showed residents "want to be heard". "We know from the election results that we saw the bush vote support the Voice," Ms Fyles said. "The bush vote, we do need to take note of that. "How can we ensure that we continue to hear the voices of those in the bush?" Ms Fyles said her government would look at its current processes to help close the gap between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians. "Is there more work to do? Yes," she said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Remote polling results show residents 'want to be heard': NT chief minister

props.alt: Natasha Fyles stands in front of news media microphones

children.content: NT Chief Minister Natasha Fyles hoped for a Yes outcome in the referendum.
(ABC News: Peter Garnish, file)
By Lauren Roberts
The NT's chief minister said she was "disappointed" by the referendum results on Saturday night and now was the time to "reflect" on how to support the community moving forward.
Chief Minister Natasha Fyles said numbers from remote polling stations in the Northern Territory showed residents "want to be heard".
"We know from the election results that we saw the bush vote support the Voice," Ms Fyles said.
"The bush vote, we do need to take note of that.
"How can we ensure that we continue to hear the voices of those in the bush?"
Ms Fyles said her government would look at its current processes to help close the gap between Indigenous and non-Indigenous Australians.
"Is there more work to do? Yes," she said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This morning Opposition Leader Peter Dutton appears to be backing away from his commitment to hold a second referendum on recognition of Indigenous Australians in the constitution if he is elected prime minister. Last month, Mr Dutton told Sky News he would hold a referendum to recognise First Australians in the constitution if he was elected, saying: "I believe very strongly it is the right thing to do." But speaking to reporters in Canberra this morning about the federal opposition's Indigenous policy, Mr Dutton said it was clear Australians were "over" the referendum process. "Look, all of our policy, obviously as I said on Saturday night, is going to be reviewed in the process that Kerrynne [Liddle] and Jacinta [Nampijinpa Price] will lead now," he said. "I think that [constitutional recognition] is important, but I think it's clear that the Australian public is probably over the referendum process for some time." The position puts him at odds with some of his Coalition colleagues, including Senator Price.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Peter Dutton softens on commitment to hold second referendum if elected

props.alt: Peter Dutton wearing glasses and a suit and red tie

children.content: Peter Dutton.
(ABC News)
This morning Opposition Leader
Peter Dutton

appears to be backing away from his commitment to hold a second referendum on recognition of Indigenous Australians in the constitution if he is elected prime minister.
Last month,
Mr Dutton told Sky News he would hold a referendum to recognise First Australians in the constitution
Â
if he was elected, saying: "I believe very strongly it is the right thing to do."
Â
But speaking to reporters in Canberra this morning about the federal opposition's Indigenous policy, Mr Dutton said it was clear Australians were "over" the referendum process.
"Look, all of our policy, obviously as I said on Saturday night, is going to be reviewed in the process that Kerrynne [Liddle] and Jacinta [Nampijinpa Price] will lead now," he said.
"I think that [constitutional recognition] is important, but I think it's clear that the Australian public is probably over the referendum process for some time."
The position puts him at odds with some of his Coalition colleagues, including Senator Price.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Melbourne's list manager Tim Lamb is on Trade Radio currently, and has provided a definitive answer as to Harrison Petty's future in the wake of interest from Adelaide. When asked if Petty will be a Demon next year: "100 per cent. That's 100 per cent. "We've had a number of chats with Harrison. He's a really good player, that's why Adelaide want to get him and that's why we're keeping him. "We'll work to hopefully have him for an extended period."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Harrison Petty will not be leaving Melbourne

children.content: (Getty Images)
Melbourne's list manager Tim Lamb is on Trade Radio currently, and has provided a definitive answer as to Harrison Petty's future in the wake of interest from Adelaide.
When asked if Petty will be a Demon next year:
"100 per cent. That's 100 per cent.
"We've had a number of chats with Harrison. He's a really good player, that's why Adelaide want to get him and that's why we're keeping him.
"We'll work to hopefully have him for an extended period."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Firstly, a mea culpa. Last week I told you that there would be no trades over the weekend. That is because there are never any trades over the weekend. Well, guess what? There was a trade on the weekend. West Coast have trade picks 44 and 63 to Hawthorn for Tyler Brockman. Pretty decent deal all round. Eagles get a player with massive potential for very little outlay, Hawks get some picks that will end up handy in matching father-son bids.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tyler Brockman has been traded to West Coast

children.content: (Getty Images)
Firstly, a mea culpa. Last week I told you that there would be no trades over the weekend. That is because there are never any trades over the weekend.
Well, guess what? There was a trade on the weekend.
West Coast have trade picks 44 and 63 to Hawthorn for Tyler Brockman.
Pretty decent deal all round. Eagles get a player with massive potential for very little outlay, Hawks get some picks that will end up handy in matching father-son bids.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There's heaps. Too many to mention straight up here. But here are some of the biggies. Esava Ratugolea to Port Adelaide. Geelong want more than the offered pick 24 Lachie Schultz to Collingwood. Pies have offered Freo pick 19, but the Dockers are looking at their future first round pick instead Liam Henry to St Kilda. Saints don't want to cough up pick 13 or pick 21 Brandon Zerk-Thatcher to Port Adelaide and Xavier Duursma to Essendon. Is a straight swap in the offing? Shane McAdam to Melbourne. Dees are offering a future second, Crows have been trying (and failing) to get a move for Harrison Petty going with it Jack Gunston to Hawthorn. Hawks have been clear this isn't their priority, but could still be done later in the week Mabior Chol to Hawthorn, Jacob Koschitzke to Richmond. Every chance these end up linked with the Suns getting involved in a three-way trade Paddy Dow to St Kilda, Nick Coffield to Western Bulldog s. Another pair of deals that could be unlocked in a multi-club deal with some draft picks moving around

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's key stock indicies are down at midday The ASX 200 is off 0.15% or -10.7 points to 7,040.4 points and the broader All Ordinaries (that covers our largest 500 listed companies) down -0.2% or -16.1 points to 7,227.4 points. The decline is pretty broad. Of the 200 firms involved in the ASX 200, 128 have lost value, 60 are up and 12 are flat. Big day for several gold producers. (The price of the shiny stuff is marginally down but it's a store of value in bad times). Not so good for Fletcher Building, Block, Star Entertainment and others.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Birkenstock, the maker of sandals so iconic they've been exported around the world and featured in the Barbie movie, floated on the New York Stock Exchange last week. Shares slumped 13% on opening day and it's kept going from there. IFR News called it: "One of the worst starts for a major US IPO and almost certainly the death knell for hopes of a significant rebound in new issues in the final three months of the year." (As in, 'Who on earth would be dumb enough to float a company between now and Christmas after this debacle?'). Shares dropped another 6.6% to US$37.55 in their second session on Thursday. "A punchy valuation, poor timing, buyside skittishness and a vain effort to create scarcity in the stock marred the sandal-maker's NYSE offering, forcing sponsor L Catterton to accept a price in the lower half of the marketing range". Who to blame? Private equity's system of buying something and then trying to sell it for way more is chief among the issues. Private equity firm L Catterton pitched Birkenstock as being worth US$10 billion. But that's more than twice what the private equity firm paid for the company in April 2021. The market now has the company valued at US$6.8 billion.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Birkenstock floats... sinks

children.content: Birkenstock, the maker of sandals so iconic they've been exported around the world and featured in the Barbie movie, floated on the New York Stock Exchange last week.
Shares slumped 13% on opening day and it's kept going from there.
IFR News called it:
"One of the worst starts for a major US IPO and almost certainly the death knell for hopes of a significant rebound in new issues in the final three months of the year."
(As in, 'Who on earth would be dumb enough to float a company between now and Christmas after this debacle?').
Shares dropped another 6.6% to US$37.55 in their second session on Thursday.

"A punchy valuation, poor timing, buyside skittishness and a vain effort to create scarcity in the stock marred the sandal-maker's NYSE offering, forcing sponsor L Catterton to accept a price in the lower half of the marketing range".
Who to blame? Private equity's system of buying something and then trying to sell it for way more is chief among the issues.
Private equity firm L Catterton pitched Birkenstock as being worth US$10 billion. But that's more than twice what the private equity firm paid for the company in April 2021.
The market now has the company valued at US$6.8 billion.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hard to believe, but here it is. PwC Australia's human resources boss Catherine Walsh was in front of the Senate, being grilled about the many failings of the firm. The incoming boss of PwC Australia was criticised for bringing Ms Walsh, because she was so new in the role and couldn't answer questions about the historic allegations the committee is investigating - and the 'now and future' problems they've created. Asked about her status in the firm, she responded: "I have been with the firm for three years and I've been in my current role as chief people officer since July." And today, she's gone! Ms Walsh will become Chief People Officer at Qantas, a press release has announced. "In this new role, Ms Walsh will help drive a stronger relationship between Qantas and its 25,000 employees, as well as with the unions that represent them. This function will also help lead the recruitment of thousands of new roles across the Group in coming years as it takes delivery of new aircraft and returns to growth." The airline has a bit of work to do in the 'HR space'... it fought it's own employees all the way to the appeals court of the High Court, losing all the way, after it sacked 1700 of them illegally. As was reported at the time: Qantas maintained it made the decision for sound commercial reasons after its business plummeted by more than 90 per cent. But the Transport Workers' Union (TWU) told the High Court the airline had also been motivated to head off industrial action when things returned to normal. The union said the sackings were in breach of the Fair Work Act, which prohibited actions that interfered with a worker's rights. Ms Walsh will start in January 2024.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Catherine Walsh addicted to hard jobs

children.content: Hard to believe, but here it is.
PwC Australia's human resources boss
Catherine Walsh
Â
was in front of the Senate, being grilled about the many failings of the firm.

The incoming boss of PwC Australia was criticised for bringing Ms Walsh, because she was so new in the role and couldn't answer questions about the historic allegations the committee is investigating - and the 'now and future' problems they've created.
Asked about her status in the firm, she responded:
"I have been with the firm for three years and I've been in my current role as chief people officer since July."
And today, she's gone!
Ms Walsh will become Chief People Officer at Qantas, a press release has announced.

"In this new role, Ms Walsh will help drive a stronger relationship between Qantas and its 25,000 employees, as well as with the unions that represent them. This function will also help lead the recruitment of thousands of new roles across the Group in coming years as it takes delivery of new aircraft and returns to growth."
The airline has a bit of work to do in the 'HR space'... it fought it's own employees all the way to the appeals court of the High Court, losing all the way, after it
sacked 1700 of them illegally
As was reported at the time:
Qantas maintained it made the decision for sound commercial reasons after its business plummeted by more than 90 per cent.
But the Transport Workers' Union (TWU) told the High Court the airline had also been motivated to head off industrial action when things returned to normal.
The union said the sackings were in breach of the Fair Work Act,
Â
which prohibited
Â
actions that
Â
interfered with a worker's rights.
Ms Walsh will start in January 2024.

props.alt: A woman with short brown hair and a navy blue shirt looking solemnly ahead.

children.content: Catherine Walsh is taking off from PwC for a new career path at Qantas.
(AAP: Mick Tsikas)
